questions.text: Identify the condenser in the following image.
questions.solution:
This is a modern compound microscope, and the condenser is located below the stage.

The purpose of the condenser lens is to focus the light from the illuminator onto the specimen. Microscopes with a stage condenser lens render a sharper image than those with no condenser lens.

The simple microscope was invented first by Antonie van Leeuwenhoek, the father of microscopy and microbiology. It uses 1 lens for magnification. The compound microscope, introduced by Hans and Zacharias Janssen uses 2 lenses, an objective lens and an eyepiece, to provide better magnification power than the simple microscope.

questions.text: A 28-year-old sex worker presented with a painless ulcer on her vulva. On examination, inguinal lymphadenopathy is present. Which of the following methods has been used to demonstrate the causative agent as per the given image?
questions.solution:
A painless genital ulcer with inguinal lymphadenopathy with the presence of spiral organisms on microscopy is suggestive of syphilis. It is caused by Treponema pallidum, demonstrated by dark-field microscopy. 

Dark-field microscopy images have a dark background with a refractile organism. The dark ground microscope has an optical system that enhances the contrast of unstained bodies. It uses reflected light and has a higher resolving power than the light microscope. Dark-field microscopy is the the most specific and sensitive technique to visualize Treponema pallidum when an active chancre or condyloma lata is present.

Other options:

Option B: Phase contrast microscopy improves the contrast to delineate structures within cells. A dark image is formed on a light background.

Option C: Fluorescent microscopy uses fluorescent dyes like auramine-rhodamine to appreciate Mycobacterial species and malarial parasites. 

Option D: The electron microscope, invented by Ernst Ruska, helps in appreciating viral structures. It has a very high resolving power. 

Related Pearl: Stages of syphilis

Primary syphilis:

  • Chancre - Painless, indurated, usually single. The chancre self heals in 1-4 months.
  • Lymphadenopathy - Painless, unilateral or bilateral, shotty and rubbery inguinal nodes
  • Dory flop sign - As the chancre is too hard to fold, it will flip over once the prepuce is retracted back.

Secondary syphilis:

  • A & B: Generalized non-itchy rash with no vesicles present on the palm and sole. This is the most common lesion.
  • C & D: Condyloma lata.
  • E: Moth-eaten non-scarring alopecia
  • F: Mucous patches are flat erosions on the tongue that can coalesce to form snail track ulcers. These are the most infectious lesions.
  • G: Pigmentary plaques
  • H: Psoriasiform syphilitic lesions
  • Generalized diffuse non-tender lymphadenopathy

Tertiary syphilis:

  • Gummatous syphilis are deep punched-out ulcers, with gum-like secretions on the floor
  • Pseudo-chancre redux is a gumma occurring at the site of a previously healed ulcer  
  • CVS - Aortitis and aneurysm of the ascending aorta
  • CNS - General paresis of the insane and tabes dorsalis 

Latent syphilis is the period between secondary and tertiary syphilis. In this period the patient is asymptomatic clinically and only serological evidence of the infection is present. It is classified into:

  • Early latent syphilis - Within 1 year of infection
  • Late latent syphilis - After 1 year of infection

questions.text: Which among the following statements is false?

choices.text: Muramic acid is present in prokaryotes
Mitotic division is present in eukaryotes
Multiple linear chromosomes present in eukaryotes

questions.solution:
80S ribosome is present in eukaryotes, while 70S ribosome is present in prokaryotes.

80S ribosome has subunits 60S and 40S, while 70S has subunits 50S and 30S.

Related Pearl: Differentiating features between prokaryotes and eukaryotes

Eukaryotes

Nucleolus

Present

Absent

Present

More than one (linear)

Absent

Present

Cytoplasmic streaming

Absent

Present

Pinocytosis

Absent

Present

Mitochondria

Absent

Present

Lysosomes

Absent

Present

Golgi apparatus

Absent

Present

Endoplasmic reticulum

Absent

Present

Ribosomes

70S

80S

Cell wall

Present

Muramic acid present

Absent

(if present, muramic acid is absent)

Sterols (In cell membrane)

Absent 

Present

questions.text: Which of the following methods will not help you visualize the bacterial cell wall?
questions.solution:
The cell wall of bacteria cannot be seen with simple stains or direct light microscopy.

The bacterial cell wall is present outside the plasma membrane and confers strength and shape to the cell. It is composed of peptidoglycans. The cell wall can be demonstrated by the following methods:

  • Plasmolysis
  • Microdissection
  • Reaction with specific antibodies
  • Mechanical rupture of the cell
  • Differential staining procedures (E.g. Chance's method)
  • Electron microscopy
  • Fluorescence microscopy

questions.text: In which of the following phases of the bacterial growth curve does sporulation occur?
questions.solution:
Sporulation occurs in the stationary phase of the bacterial growth curve, which is marked as C in the image.

The bacterial growth curve is obtained when a batch of bacteria is seeded in a liquid medium and incubated. It consists of 4 distinct phases:

  1. Lag phase (A) - The bacteria adapt to a new environment. They synthesize and accumulate enzymes and metabolic intermediates required for multiplication. Thus, there is no increase in cell number but cell size increases. Maximum cell size is obtained towards the end of this phase.
  2. Log or exponential phase (B) - The bacteria start dividing and their numbers increase exponentially with time. Cells are smaller and stain uniformly. The growth rate is constant. 
  3. Stationary phase (C) - There is depletion of nutrients and accumulation of toxic products. Thus, cell division reduces and a state of equilibrium is attained, where the number of new cells formed equals the number that die. Growth rate is zero. Sporulation occurs during this phase. Many bacteria produce secondary metabolic products such as exotoxins and antibiotics.
  4. Death phase or the phase of decline (D) - Growth rate is negative. The population decreases due to cell death from nutritional exhaustion, toxin accumulation and the action of autolytic enzymes. Involution forms are common.

questions.text: Which organism has the following cell wall structure?
questions.solution:
The presence of teichoic acid and lipoteichoic acid with a thick peptidoglycan layer is a feature of gram-positive bacteria. 

The cell wall of bacteria provides shape and ridigity to the bacterial cell. It is composed of peptidoglycans.

  Gram positive Gram negative
Teichoic acid, lipoteichoic acid Present Absent
Thickness (Peptidoglycan) Thicker Thinner
Variety of amino acids Few Several
Aromatic and sulfur-containing amino acids Absent Present
Lipopolysaccharides and outer membrane Absent Present

 

Other options:

Option C: The cell wall of fungi consists of chitin, mannan, and polysaccharides (glucan).

Option D: The cell wall of mycobacteria have mycolic acid, which is responsible for acid fastness.

questions.text: Which of the following helps in bacterial adhesion?
questions.solution:
Fimbriae help in bacterial adhesion.

Fimbriae, also called pili, are hair-like surface appendage that projects from the cell surface as straight filaments. They are primarily seen in Gram-negative bacteria. They are polymers of pilin. Fimbriae are classified based on the function as ordinary pili - for adhesion - and sex pili - involved in bacterial conjugation. The functions of pili are given below:

  • Bacterial conjugation through sex pili, which transfer of genetic material occurs.
  • Bacterial adhesion of symbiotic and pathogenic bacteria to host cells using adhesins.
  • Resistance to phagocytosis.
  • Antigenic pilin proteins are responsible for the immune response.
  • Twitching motility to bacteria.

questions.text: Pasteurization is done at  ______.
questions.solution:
Pasteurization is done at 63 degree Celsius for 30 minutes.

Pasteurization is the process of applying heat to milk to kill or stunt the growth of pathogenic bacteria. It was developed by Louis Pasteur. There are two methods for pasteurization:

  • Holder method: Milk is heated at 63°C for 30 minutes
  • Flash process: Milk is heated to 72°C for 15–20 seconds

Once heated appropriately, the milk is cooled quickly to 13°C or lower. All the non-sporing pathogens (mycobacteria, brucellae, salmonellae) are killed in pasteurization. In the Holder method, heat resistant Coxiella burnetti may survive. 

Note: Louis Pasteur pioneered the techniques of pasteurization and sterilization. He also first advanced the germ theory of disease which states that most diseases were caused by microorganisms. Furthermore, he disproved the theory of spontaneous generation and developed vaccines for rabies and fowl cholera. He is thus known as the father of modern microbiology.

Related Pearl: Methods of Sterilization and Disinfection

  Spectrum Uses
1. Heat    
Hot air oven All Glasswares, sterilizing powders, oils, swabs and dressings
Autoclaving All Linen, surgical instruments, laboratory ware, media and pharmaceutical products
Boiling Most pathogens, some spores Metal tools, rubber or plastic equipment, cloth 
Pasteurization Vegetative bacteria Beverages, plastic hospital equipment
2. Ethylene oxide gas All Heat-sensitive equipment like heart-lung machines, artificial valves, fabrics, respirators, cardiac catheters, books
3. Radiation    
UV All Limited value due to poor penetration, can be used for plastic syringes, catheters, and laboratory cabinets
Ionising All Surgical supplies, food
4. Chemicals    
Alcohol Vegetative bacteria, viruses some spores Skin disinfection, hand washing
Hydrogen peroxide Viruses, vegetative bacteria, spores and fungi High-level disinfectant, antiseptic for wounds and discharging ulcers
Chlorine Viruses, vegetative bacteria, fungi To disinfect water
Iodophors Viruses, vegetative bacteria, fungi, lethal to spore-bearing organisms Skin disinfection, disinfect blood culture bottles and medical equipment
Crude phenol Gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria, but only slowly effective against spores and acid-fast bacteria. Disinfection of faeces, mopping floors and cleaning drains.
5. Glutaraldehyde   All Endoscopes, bronchoscopes
6. Quarternary ammonium compounds Most bacteria, fungi, lipophilic viruses  General cleaning

questions.text: Which of the following methods of sterilization involves exposure to 100 °C for 20 minutes on 3 successive days?
questions.solution:
The method of sterilization that involves exposure at 100°C for 20 minutes for 3 successive days is called tyndallization or intermittent sterilization. 

Tyndallization, which utilizes steam, was used for sterilization of media containing gelatin, egg, serum, or sugar. This method may not kill spores of certain anaerobes and thermophiles. Autoclaving has replaced this method now. 

Other options:

Option A: Autoclaving involves heating at 121°C for 15 minutes at a pressure of 15psi. This is the used for intruments, linen, laboratory ware.

Option C: In pasteurization, milk is heated at either 63°C for 30 minutes (the holder method) or at 72°C for 15–20 seconds (the flash process), followed by cooling quickly to 13°C or lower. 

Option D: Heating an article at 80–85 °C for 30 minutes on 3 consecutive days is called inspissation. 

Related Pearl: Methods of Sterilization and Disinfection

  Spectrum Uses
1. Heat    
Hot air oven All Glasswares, sterilizing powders, oils, swabs and dressings
Autoclaving All Linen, surgical instruments, laboratory ware, media and pharmaceutical products
Boiling Most pathogens, some spores Metal tools, rubber or plastic equipment, cloth 
Pasteurization Vegetative bacteria Beverages, plastic hospital equipment
2. Ethylene oxide gas All Heat-sensitive equipment like heart-lung machines, artificial valves, fabrics, respirators, cardiac catheters, books
3. Radiation    
UV All Limited value due to poor penetration, can be used for plastic syringes, catheters, and laboratory cabinets
Ionising All Surgical supplies, food
4. Chemicals    
Alcohol Vegetative bacteria, viruses some spores Skin disinfection, hand washing
Hydrogen peroxide Viruses, vegetative bacteria, spores and fungi High-level disinfectant, antiseptic for wounds and discharging ulcers
Chlorine Viruses, vegetative bacteria, fungi To disinfect water
Iodophors Viruses, vegetative bacteria, fungi, lethal to spore-bearing organisms Skin disinfection, disinfect blood culture bottles and medical equipment
Crude phenol Gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria, but only slowly effective against spores and acid-fast bacteria. Disinfection of faeces, mopping floors and cleaning drains.
5. Glutaraldehyde   All Endoscopes, bronchoscopes
6. Quarternary ammonium compounds Most bacteria, fungi, lipophilic viruses  General cleaning

questions.text: Which of the following works by disrupting the cell membrane?
questions.solution:
Lysol works by disrupting the cell membrane. 

Lysol is a phenol compound, which is obtained by distillation of coal tar. Phenols cause cell membrane damage and inactivate membrane-bound oxidases and dehydrogenases. This causes lysis and release of cell contents. Low concentrations of phenol can precipitate proteins. They are not inactivated by organic matter and are thus useful disinfectants. 

The mechnisms of action of other disinfecting agents are:

  1. DNA damage
    • Ionizing radiation
    • Ultraviolet light
    • Hydrogen peroxide
    • DNA reactive chemicals like acriflavin. 
  2. Protein modification
    • Alcohol
    • Chlorine
    • Iodine
    • Heavy metals (e.g. thiomersal)
    • Hydrogen peroxide
    • Formaldehyde
    • Glutaraldehyde
    • Ethylene oxide
    • Acids and alkalis

questions.text: Which of the following methods is used in the test shown below?
questions.solution:
The given image shows antibiotic sensitivity testing which uses the lawn culture method.

Lawn or carpet culture is the method in which a uniform surface growth of bacterium is present on the medium. It is used for antibiotic sensitivity testing (disc method) and bacteriophage typing. Stab culture (option D) is used for demonstration of gelatin liquefaction and oxygen requirements of bacterium, for maintenance of stock cultures. Streak culture (option A) is routinely used for the isolation of bacteria in pure culture from clinical specimens. Stroke culture (option C) is used for providing pure growth of bacterium for slide agglutination and other diagnostic tests. Other methods of culture include: 

  • Liquid culture - These are preferred for inocula containing antibiotics and other inhibitory substances.
  • Pour plate culture - It gives an estimate of viable bacterial count in a suspension.

questions.text: In which of the following organisms will the following phenomenon not be observed in?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Quellung reaction (halo around the bacteria) and is seen in capsulated bacteria. Neisseria gonorrhoeae is not capsulated, therefore Quellung reaction will not be observed in it. 

In Quellung reaction, a suspension of a capsulated bacterium is mixed with its specific anticapsular serum and examined under the microscope. The anticapsular antibodies bind to the capsule and thus the capsule becomes very prominent and appears swollen. Capsulated organisms can be remembered with the following mnemonic: 

Some - Streptococcus pneumoniae

Killers - Klebsiella pneumoniae

Have - Haemophilus influenzae

Nice - Neisseria meningitidis

Capsules - Cryptococcus neoformans

Related Pearl: Types of capsules in microorganisms

Capsule  Organsim
Polysaccharide capsule 

 Streptococcus pneumonia

 Klebsiella pneumonia

 Hemophilius influenza

 Neiserria meningitidis

 Salmonella typhi

 Cryptococcus neoformans

 Bordetella pertussis

Clostridium perfringens
Hyaluronic acid capsule  Streptococcus pyogenes
Polypeptide (Poly-D -Glutamate) Capsule  Bacillus anthracis
F1 Protein Capsule  Yersinia pestis

questions.text: A 32-year-old laborer working at a construction site presented with fever and hemoptysis. The sputum sample collected for examination showed the following. The smear will be stained by which of the following sequences?

choices.text: Methylene blue - malachite green- acetic acid-water

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of fever and hemoptysis in a labourer with the sputum smear showing acid-fast bacilli is suggestive of tuberculosis. Mycobacterium tuberculosis, detected on sputum smear, is appreciated by Ziehl-Neelsen staining, which would includes carbol fuschin - acid - alcohol - methylene blue. 

Acid-fast bacteria (like MTB) in a stained Ziehl-Neelsen (ZN) smear appear bright red against a blue background. Steps involved in ZN staining are:

  • Place the sample on slide evenly spread it with rotational movement
  • Air-dry the slide and fix it by passing it over a flame
  • Apply carbol fuschin stain and heat to fix it.
  • Wash with water to remove excess stain
  • Decolourise with alcohol
  • Apply Methylene blue/Malachite green stain
  • Wash with water to remove excess stain
  • View under the microscope

Kinyoun modified the classical ZN staining such that heat fixing is not required. It is called the cold method. It involves increasing the concentration of phenol acid and the duration of staining. The slide is then washed with water and decolourized with acid alcohol. Counterstaining with Loeffler's methylene blue or malachite green is done for a minute and viewed under a microscope. Acid-fast bacteria in a stained smear appear bright red against a blue background.  

The image attached below summarizes the steps.

Option A: It depicts the order of Gram staining, which was discovered by Hans Christian Gram in 1884.

  • Primary staining with para-rosaniline dye (crystal violet, methyl violet or gentian violet).
  • Application of dilute solution of iodine.
  • Decolorisation with an organic solvent (ethanol, acetone, aniline).
  • Counterstaining with the dye of contrasting colour (carbol fuchsin, safranine, neutral red).

 Option B: It includes the steps for performing Albert's stain which is used for detected Corynebacterium diphtheriae. 

  • A heavy smear of the bacterial isolate is prepared on a glass slide and allowed to dry without fixing.
  • Albert’s stain is applied for (3-4) minutes. Then it is washed with water and Albert’s iodine is applied for one minute.
  • Wash with water and let dry with blotting paper.
  • Examine the slide under oil immersion.

Corynebacterium diphtheriae are slender bacilli with an arrangement resembling the letters V or L. They have metachromatic granules at the poles of bacilli which are also called polar bodies, volutin, or Babes-Ernst granules. Albert staining is useful in the demonstration of metachromatic granules. The presence of metachromatic granules helps to distinguish C.diphtheriae from diphtheroids which lack them. The images below show Corynebacterium diphtheriae. 

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens
Basic stains.

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains:

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor white staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain calcofluor white. It is especially useful for the identification of mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.  It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For cell wall demonstration

Related Pearl: Acid fast Organisms

Acid-fast organisms Sulfuric acid (%) required for decolorization 
  • Mycobacterium tuberculosis 
 25%
  • Mycobacterium leprae
 5%

 

  • Eggs of Taenia saginata
  • Eggs of Schistosoma mansoni
  • Oocyst of Cryptosporidium
  • Oocyst of Cyclospora
  • Oocyst of Cystoisospora
 1%
  • Sperm head
  • Legionella micdadei
  • Nocardia
 0.5-1%
  • Bacterial spore
 0.25-0.5%

questions.text:
Given are a few case scenarios. The etiological agents of which of the following are microaerophilic?
  1. Endoscopic biopsy from a businessman with epigastric pain showing positive urease test.
  2. Gram-negative, small, spirally curved rod-like, motile bacilli isolated from a patient with diarrhea.
  3. Gram-negative curved bacilli with 'fish-in-stream' appearance isolated from a child with rice-water diarrhea.
  4. Nasopharyngeal swab from a child with paroxysmal cough showing 'mercury drop' colonies. 
  5. Sputum from a farmer, cultured on LJ medium showing dry, rough, raised, irregular colonies.
questions.solution:
The aetiological agents of 1 and 2 are microaerophilic. 

The given case scenarios are:

1. A businessman with epigastric pain and positive urease test has peptic ulcer disease, caused by Helicobacter pylori. It is microaerophilic.
2. Diarrhea caused by Gram-negative, small, spirally curved rod-like, motile bacilli describes Campylobacter jejuni. It is microaerophilic.
3. Rice-water diarrhea and Gram-negative curved bacilli with 'fish-in-stream' appearance describes cholera caused by Vibrio cholerae. It is a facultative anaerobe.
4. Nasopharyngeal swab from a child with paroxysmal cough showing 'mercury drops' colonies describes Bordetella pertussis. It is an obligate aerobe.
5. Dry, rough, raised, irregular colonies on LJ medium describes Mycobacerium tuberculosis. It is an obligate aerobe.

Microaerophilic organisms grow best in low oxygen tension (2-10% oxygen).

Note: Mycobacteria, such as M. bovis, can grow at oxygen tensions ranging from atmospheric to microaerophilic conditions. However, M. tuberculosis is an obligate aerobe.

Related Pearl: Oxygen Requirements of Bacteria

Type of organism

 Feature Examples 
Obligate Aerobes

Always require oxygen for their growth. 

Cannot ferment or respire anaerobically.

M.tuberculosis 

Bacillus sp

Legionella sp

Bordetella sp

Pseudomonas aeruginosa
Obligate Anaerobes

 

Can't grow in the presence of oxygen as most of them don’t have Superoxide dismutase and Catalase.

 

Clostridium sp.

Bacteroides sp.
Micro-aerophilic

Require small amounts of oxygen (2–10%) for aerobic respiration. Higher oxygen concentrations are inhibitory.

H. pylori

Campylobacter jejuni 

M.bovis
Facultative anaerobe

Can grow aerobically or anaerobically based on the surrounding environment

Many organisms including Enteric gram-negative bacteria, S. aureus, Vibrio cholerae
Aero-tolerant

Are indifferent to Oxygen. They are basically anaerobic organisms but can tolerate oxygen.

Peptococcus anaerobius

Lactobacillus sp.

questions.text: The given image shows a culture medium with lactose fermenting and non-lactose fermenting bacteria. Which of the following is not a component of the culture medium?
questions.solution:
The given image shows MacConkey agar. Cysteine is not a constituent of MacConkey agar. 

MacConkey agar is a differential or indicator medium. Lactose-fermenting organisms (Eg: E. coli) produce a pink color, and non-lactose fermenting organisms (Shigella sp., Salmonella sp.) do not change the color. Contents of MacConkey agar include peptone, lactose, agar, neutral red and sodium taurocholate (Mnemonic- PLANT). MacConkey agar is also a selective medium i.e. the bile salts (sodium taurocholate) and dyes (neutral red) inhibit the growth of Gram-positive organisms and Gram-negative cocci.

questions.text: Which of the following is an enrichment medium?
questions.solution:
The image 'A' represents alkaline peptone water, which is an enrichment medium used for Vibrio cholerae.

The other images represent:

Image B- Blood agar with P. aeruginosa colonies 

Image C- Loeffler's serum slope, which is used to isolate C. diphtheriae

Image D- Chocolate agar with F. tularensis colonies

Enrichment media suppress the growth of commensal bacteria and allow for the growth of certain organisms. These media are used for samples with mixed flora e.g. stool. They are always liquid media, like alkaline peptone water. Other examples include tetrathionate broth and selenite-F broth for Salmonella sp. and Shigella sp.

Enriched medium are those media to which additional nutrients such as blood, serum, or egg are added. They're used to grow bacteria with specific nutritional requirements. Examples include blood agar to test the hemolytic property of bacteria, chocolate agar for isolation of H. influenzae and Loeffler's serum slope for isolation of C. diphtheriae.

questions.text: A microbiologist observes the following growth on a blood agar plate. Which of the following will not be the etiological agent?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a swarming type of growth on the agar plate. It will not be caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

Swarming is the growth of motile bacteria in the form of a thin film on solid culture media. It is exhibited by the following:

  • Gram-positive bacilli - Clostridium tetani (option A), Bacillus cereus (option D)
  • Gram-negative bacilli - Proteus mirabilis (option C), Proteus vulgaris
  • Gram-negative halophilic bacteria- Vibrio parahaemolyticus 

Swarming can be inhibited by increasing the concentration of agar (6%), alcohol, sodium azide, boric acid, chloral hydrate, sulfonamide, and surface-active agents.

questions.text: Bacterial transduction occurs by

choices.text: Uptake of genetic material by other bacteria.

questions.solution:
Bacterial transduction occurs by bacteriophages.

Transduction is a process of acquiring bacterial DNA from a bacteriophage (virus) that has incorporated bacterial DNA from previous host bacteria.

Other methods of exchange of genetic material are transformation and conjugation. Transformation involves the uptake of genetic material from the environment, which is released by other bacteria. Conjugation is the direct transfer of DNA from one bacterial cell to another bacterial cell through a sex pilus or bridge. The transferred DNA is a plasmid, a circle of DNA that is distinct from the main bacterial chromosome.

questions.text: Which of the following principles is primarily used in polymerase chain reaction?

choices.text: It can amplify small amounts of DNA
It can amplify small amounts of RNA

questions.solution:
The primary principle used in polymerase chain reaction (PCR) is the amplification of small amounts of DNA. 

PCR is an automated process in which a single or a few copies of a DNA piece is amplified to generate of thousands to millions of copies of that particular DNA sequence. There are 3 basic steps are involved in PCR:

  • DNA extraction from microorganism
  • Amplification of extracted DNA - Denaturation (95°C), Primer annealing (55°C), Extension (72°C)
  • Gel electrophoresis of the amplified product

PCR is used in rapid diagnostic tests for infections (e.g. HIV DNA), forensic investigations etc. The founder of PCR is Karry B Mullis.

questions.text:
Which of the following describes the reverse transcriptase enzyme used in RT-PCR correctly?

(RT-PCR - Reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction)
questions.solution:
The enzyme involved in RT-PCR is reverse transcriptase (RT) which has RNA-dependent DNA polymerase activity.

In reverse transcription-polymerase chain reation (RT-PCR), reverse transcriptase synthesizes DNA from the RNA template. RT-PCR can be used for the demonstration of poliovirus RNA, causing paralytic poliomyelitis, in CSF. It can also be used for the detection of viruses from nasopharyngeal swabs (SARS-CoV2, H1N1).

In real-time RT-PCR, fluorescent dyes or DNA probes are used to quantify the pathogen DNA load in the specimen. So, it can be used to quantify viral loads in HIV, hepatitis B, etc., and is also called quantitative PCR (qPCR).

questions.text: What are jumping genes known as?
questions.solution:
Jumping genes are also called transposons.

Transposons are genetic elements that can move between chromosomal and extra-chromosomal DNA molecules. Insertion of a transposon leads to acquisition of new characteristics by the recipient DNA. Transposons contain several genes, including those necessary for their migration from one genetic locus to another. They may contain genes for specialised functions like antibiotic resistance. However, they do not contain genes for their replication.

Jumping genes were discovered by Barbara McClintock and she was awarded the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine 1983 for the same. 

Other options: 

Options A and B: The cytoplasmic carriers of genetic information are termed plasmids or episomes.

Option D: A cosmid is a type of hybrid plasmid that contains a Lambda phage cos sequence. (Cos sites + plasmid = cosmids).

questions.text:
In which of the following situations will you use a sanitizer?

A. Before examining the patient
B. After examining the patient
C. After touching the patient's surroundings
D. Hands are visibly soiled
questions.solution:
You should use a sanitiser before and after examining the patient and after touching the patients' surroundings. The hands should be washed with soap and water thoroughly in case they are visibly soiled.

Sanitization is the process through which pathogenic organisms are reduced to safe levels on inanimate objects to reduce the likelihood of cross-infections. It is a component of hand-hygiene, which is demonstrated by the image below. 

Note: Disinfectants like chlorhexidine and alexidine have a biguanide functional group. They are mostly used as oral disinfectants and hand products. They are bactericidal but not sporicidal. Mycobacteria are also resistant to these compounds.

Related Pearl: Methods of Sterilization and Disinfection

  Spectrum Uses
1. Heat    
Hot air oven All Glasswares, sterilizing powders, oils, swabs and dressings
Autoclaving All Linen, surgical instruments, laboratory ware, media and pharmaceutical products
Boiling Most pathogens, some spores Metal tools, rubber or plastic equipment, cloth 
Pasteurization Vegetative bacteria Beverages, plastic hospital equipment
2. Ethylene oxide gas All Heat-sensitive equipment like heart-lung machines, artificial valves, fabrics, respirators, cardiac catheters, books
3. Radiation    
UV All Limited value due to poor penetration, can be used for plastic syringes, catheters, and laboratory cabinets
Ionising All Surgical supplies, food
4. Chemicals    
Alcohol Vegetative bacteria, viruses some spores Skin disinfection, hand washing
Hydrogen peroxide Viruses, vegetative bacteria, spores and fungi High-level disinfectant, antiseptic for wounds and discharging ulcers
Chlorine Viruses, vegetative bacteria, fungi To disinfect water
Iodophors Viruses, vegetative bacteria, fungi, lethal to spore-bearing organisms Skin disinfection, disinfect blood culture bottles and medical equipment
Crude phenol Gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria, but only slowly effective against spores and acid-fast bacteria. Disinfection of faeces, mopping floors and cleaning drains.
5. Glutaraldehyde   All Endoscopes, bronchoscopes
6. Quarternary ammonium compounds Most bacteria, fungi, lipophilic viruses  General cleaning

questions.text: An orthopedician is performing the following procedure to visualize the anterior cruciate ligament in a patient. Which of the following will be used to sterilise the instrument used?
questions.solution:
The given image shows arthroscopy being performed. Arthroscopes are sterilized using plasma sterilization which utilises hydrogen peroxide. 

In plasma sterilisation, radiofrequency energy is applied to create an electromagnetic field through which hydrogen peroxide vapours are passed. This generates plasma which contains free radicals of hydrogen and oxygen. Plasma denatures all organisms and is used sterilize arthroscopes and ureteroscopes. Sterilization control is monitored by Geobacillus stearothermophilus and Bacillus atrophaeus. 

Option A: Ethylene oxide has both microbicidal and sporicidal activity. It is used for sterilisation heat-sensitive equipment like heart-lung machines, respirators, suture materials etc. Sterilization control is monitored by Bacillius atrophaeus and Bacillus subtilus.

Option B: Gamma rays cause breakage of DNA. It destroys spores and vegetative cells, but is not effective against viruses. It is referred to as cold sterilisation and is used in commercial plants to sterilize plastics, syringes, swabs. Sterilization control is monitored by Bacillus pumilius. 

Option D: Ultraviolet rays are used to sterilise biosafety cabinets, entryways, operation theatres and laboratories. 

Related Pearl: Methods of sterilisation

Method of disinfection or sterilisation Material
Red Heat Inoculating wire loop, tip of forceps
Incineration Contaminated clothes, animal carcasses, plastics like polythene
Hot air oven Glasswares, scalpels, forceps, cutting instruments, test tubes
Inspissator Heat labile culture media containing egg, sugar or serum
Autoclave Culture media, dressings, gloves, aprons, all instruments except sharps, suture materials except catgut
Isopropyl alcohol Clinical thermometers, stethoscopes, probes
Methyl alcohol Fungal spores

Beta propiolactone/

formaldehyde

 Fumigation of operating theatres, wards and labs
2% gluteraldehyde Cystoscopes, bronchoscopes, fibre-optic endoscopes, plastic ETT, face masks
Plasma sterilisation Arthroscopes, urethroscopes
Ethylene oxide Heart lung machines, respirators, dental equipments, sutures, books, clothings
Filtration (Seitz filters) Bacterial vaccines, intravenous solutions
5% cresol, hot air oven Sharp instruments

Ionising radiation

(Cold air sterilization)

 Catgut, swabs, plastic, syringes, needles, gloves, catheters, grafts
Chlorhexidine Disinfecting surgeon’s hands prior to surgery
Iodophor Disinfecting surgical site prior to surgery
70% ethanol Disinfectant skin prior to venepuncture or immunisation
Thiomersal Preservative in vaccine
Silver sulfadiazine Cleanse burn wounds
Hypochlorite Cleanup of blood spill from a patient with hepatitis B or C
Hydrogen peroxide Cleanse wounds
